messages.subject: 'Sin' was Re:criticism of unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ~~ I think its awesome that you have graced this board with your presence! I say this as a fellow star person. I wondered why you never came over to this
messages.messageBody:
~~
I think its awesome that you have graced this board with your
presence! I say this as a fellow "star" person. I wondered why you
never came over to this board.~~

Aw gee...now I'm blushing.:)
I used to be one of the more vocal peeps here, back when Sandra first
started it. I remember the upheaval that got this one going, as well
as UB which Kelly and I started. Anyhoo....just decided I was missing
the old gang.

Don't know how often I'll get back, what with apple trees and garden
and beehives and work and such....but it's nice to "see" some familiar
names that aren't at UB.

Ren
learninginfreedom.com

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] 'Sin' was Re:criticism of unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ... Two really important things that stuck with me after reading the Conversations with God series of books (and listening to them! Ellen Burstyn & Ed Asner as
messages.messageBody:
On Tue, Mar 11, 2008 at 3:48 PM, Sandra Dodd <Sandra@...> wrote:

> -=-Total depravity, well, there's consequences there... depravity in
>
> moderation, that's my motto ;)
> I'd have to say that Original Sin is what I'm shooting for with my
> kids...
> why do the same ol' regular sin, be Original ;-P-=-
>
> Should I say, for "the viewing public" (lurkers) that Diana is one of
> our church-going regulars? <g>
>
> And some kind of non-God-fearing comedienne.
>




Two really important things that stuck with me after reading the
Conversations with God series of books (and listening to them! Ellen Burstyn
& Ed Asner as the *God* voices :::vbg:::)
1) If we're all created in the image of "The Creator" then God's an awful
lot like me :) Which also means S/he's far less of the Fire and Brimstone
model and more of the Kooky Fun model :D
2) It's called enlightenment because we're supposed to "Lighten Up" about it
:D

If God doesn't have a sense of humor, especially when it comes to me, I'm
more okay with staying alive than I once thought ;)
For now, I'll listen to some more Depeche Mode and hang onto my deep belief
that indeed, God has a sick sense of humor and when I die I expect to find
him laughing :)
--
~diana :)
xoxoxoxo
hannahbearski.blogspot.com

On Mon, Mar 10, 2008 at 4:14 PM, Robyn L. Coburn <dezigna@...> wrote:

> <<<< The Scripture doctrines of original sin and total depravity
> > should forever end the discussion.>>>
>
> Yes, well, I daresay I would promptly end any discussion with someone who
> wanted to tell me about original sin and total depravity in reference to
> parenting. I doubt that either of us would be able to change the other
> person's viewpoint.
>



Total depravity, well, there's consequences there... depravity in
moderation, that's my motto ;)
I'd have to say that Original Sin is what I'm shooting for with my kids...
why do the same ol' regular sin, be Original ;-P

--
~diana :)
xoxoxoxo
hannahbearski.blogspot.com

messages.subject: 'Sin' was Re:criticism of unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ***** The Scripture doctrines of original sin and total depravity should forever end the discussion. ***** I m reading Eckhart Tolle s book A New Earth and
messages.messageBody:
*****
The Scripture doctrines of original sin and total depravity
should forever end the discussion.

*****

I'm reading Eckhart Tolle's book A New Earth and there's a great paragraph that immediately came to mind when I read this:
"According to Christian teachings, the normal collective state of humanity is one of 'original sin'. Sin is a word that has been greatly misunderstood an misinterpreted. Literally translated from the ancient Greek in which the New Testament was written, to sin means to miss the mark, as an archer who missed the target, so to sin means to miss the point of human existence. It means to live unskillfully, blindly, and thus to suffer and cause suffering. Again, the term, stripped of its cultural baggage and misinterpretations, points to the dysfunction inherent in the human condition."
It's a fantastic book. Full of great mind food <g>.




Meghan

I can create what I can imagine. ~ Charlene Kingston
